page.title: 06 Coppicing (1)
page.content: In Denstead Lane,near to Chartham Hatch,we interviewed two woodcutters.A lot of the 'lengths' of chestnut coppicing are carried up to a firm in Scotland to be made into snow fencing.Chestnut is used because of its strength.One of the men was the son of the fencing firm's owner Mr.D.Ramsley. The firm had been going for 30 years.They operate in a 20 mile radius of Challock.The land itself is owned by either farmers or other landowners.Areas of the coppicing called cants (defined by agreed markers that differ in each new plot) are auctioned off for cutting again every 14 years.Then it re-grows out of the side of the same root and trunk stock.The cutters have to be out of the wood by the end of May to avoid damaging the new growth.
